column11: The November rains in Weligama are creating a trash buildup in the ocean waters. I implore the government of Sri Lanka, hotels, surf camps, tourists, and local citizens to come together and make change. How does trash get into the ocean? Litter from streets and beaches carried by wind or rain, improper disposal washes into storm drains, rivers, and improper disposal from boats. What can we do to make change? Reduce single use plastics, recycle, support local legislation to decrease production of plastics, encourage use of reusable compostable non plastic bottles and bags, provide bins to dispose of trash properly, government dispose of trash in environmentally safe ways, spread the news, educate, volunteer and support charities who are trying to make change. I am a swimmer and bodysurfer and due to the trash in the ocean I do not recommend Weligama Beach. I spoke to managers at Weligama Marriott and Kai Beach Club. I am hoping there will be change from the top government and those with financial power, if not tourists will stop coming. I know I will not be returning.

column11: We have been visiting Weligama for very many years and always enjoy walking along the golden sandy beach, listening to the waves of the Indian Ocean crashing against the shore. This beach is a lively place and is good for sunbathing, surfing, walking and bathing - though we advise anyone to be careful of tides and currents. There are numerous small surfing schools along the promenade adjacent to the beach and there are many restaurants and bars in the vicinity. The beach is fairly clean, though we have seen areas that are polluted. The various fishing vessels that park on the beach also add to the very pleasant atmosphere. Hotels are multiplying rapidly in this area and accommodation will not be difficult to find.
